comments:
Driver ID: Hyades_3.3.0_20050509_0816

Hyades_3.3.0_20050509_0816 RAC was installed the on AS400 machine. After 
ran ./SetConfig and started RAC, I tested connection with AS400 machine, it 
shows "Connection Success". There is no other, older RAC is running. When I 
import log file with filter from AS400 machine, an error message pops up with 
message "An error occurred while attempting to import the log file ....
Reason: [Ljava.lang.StackTraceElement;@191fc25"
Does this problem only occur when importing with filters?

This problem only occurs when remote importing with filters.

From the RAC log file it appears there was no request to launch 
RemoteLogParserLoader.  Then I debugged the client side with a runtime 
workbench and found that the file transfer of the new adapter file threw a 
connection refused exception.  Therefore, the import operation did not proceed 
and the indicated error message was displayed.  The following exception was 
written to the development workbench console:

Further investigation on the AS/400 system showed that the file server port 
10005 was not active even though the RAC log gave no indication of a failure 
starting the file server.

Joe, transferring this to you as it appears to be a problem with the file 
server on AS/400.  Note, this scenario worked on AS/400 prior to the file 
server changes made by your team.

Raising the severity to critical because it appears the file server is not 
working on AS/400.

This failure happens because the nio classes can not be loaded.  The specific 
class that is causing the failure is java.nio.channels.ServerSocketChannel.  
This class is not listed as optional in JDK1.4

I will work this weekend on a workaround that will create the old server when 
the new impl is not able to be create due to problems such as this.  However, 
we really need the new impl for a number of performance and stability 
reasons.  If we find that nio can be used on iSeries, it would be a much 
better solution.

This fix is suboptimal, but may be the best we can do.  We now handle the 
situation when nio classes can not be loaded on the server side and we revert 
to the old file server implementation (which does not rely on nio.)  If we can 
determine that nio should be support on as/400, this newly introduced code 
will do no harm.
